title: Quentin Tarantino hits back at criticism of racial politics in his work: 'I'm not some super-villain' - Movies
text: Quentin Tarantino is pretty much disgusted by those who question the racial politics in his films.Tarantino is certainly no stranger to controversy, with his Oscar-winning Django Unchained being notably condemned by filmmaker Spike Lee for exploiting slavery. © Getty Images / Ernesto Ruscio Answering his critics in a New York Times interview, Tarantino admitted that he has been dismayed by the vitriol thrown his way over depictions of race in his movies."In a lot of the more ugly pieces my motives were really brought to bear in the most negative way [with Django Unchained]," he recalled. "It's like I'm some super-villain coming up with this stuff."The director continued: "If you sift through the criticism, you'll see it's pretty evenly divided between pros and cons. But when the black critics came out with savage think pieces about Django, I couldn't have cared less."If people don't like my movies, they don't like my movies, and if they don't get it, it doesn't matter. The bad taste that was left in my mouth had to do with this: It's been a long time since the subject of a writer's skin was mentioned as often as mine. © Vivien Killilea/Getty Images for SiriusXM "You wouldn't think the colour of a writer's skin should have any effect on the words themselves."Tarantino's latest movie The Hateful Eight is a Western set in a blizzard, as a group of dangerous strangers come together under one roof.The three-hour-plus Hateful Eight opens on Christmas Day (December 25) in the US and January 8 in the UK.
